examples.text: delicate china teacups
The eye is one of the most delicate organs of the body.
the delicate ecological balance of the rainforest
Babies have very delicate skin.
a cool wash cycle for delicate fabrics
Her bones felt as delicate as a bird's.
The glasses looked very delicate.

definitions.definition: not strong and easily becoming ill

examples.text: a **delicate child/constitution**
His health had always been delicate.
She has a delicate constitution and has to be careful with what she eats.
a rather delicate child

definitions.definition: small and having a beautiful shape or appearance

examples.text: his delicate hands

definitions.definition: made or formed in a very careful and detailed way

examples.text: the delicate mechanisms of a clock

definitions.definition: showing or needing careful or sensitive treatment

examples.text: I admired your delicate handling of the situation.
a delicate problem
The delicate surgical operation took five hours.
This is a somewhat delicate subject.
a politically delicate situation
I wasn't sure how to approach the delicate matter of pay.
He warned that the talks were at a very delicate stage.
This has done nothing except to inflame an already delicate situation.
a **delicate fragrance/flavour**
a river scene painted in delicate watercolours

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘delightful, charming’): from French délicat or Latin delicatus, of unknown origin. Senses also expressed in Middle English (now obsolete) include ‘voluptuous’, ‘self-indulgent’, ‘fastidious’, and ‘effeminate’.
